projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN ORDINANCE For bringing the Publique Revenues OF THIS COMMON-WEALTH INTO ONE TREASURIE.

body.p: ORdered by his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, and His Council, That this Ordinance be forthwith Printed and Publi≈øhed.

closer.signed: Henry Scobell, Clerk of the Council.

div.p: London, Printed by William du-Gard and Henry Hills, Printers to His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, 1654.

div.head: seal of the commonwealth of England AN ORDINANCE For bringing the Publique Revenues Of this Common-wealth into one TREASVRY.
div.p:
WHereas upon Con≈øideration had, It is found nece≈ø≈øary, That the Moneys and other payments ari≈øing by the Publique Revenues of this Common-wealth, or which ≈øhall be rai≈øed for the u≈øes thereof, ≈øhould be paid into one Trea≈øury,
to the end the ≈øame may from time to time the more readily be imployed and di≈øpo≈øed as the occa≈øions of the Common-wealth ≈øhall require.

That the Charges ari≈øing by the multiplicity of Trea≈øuries or Receipts may be reduced, and the per≈øons who ≈øhall be imployed in receiving the ≈øame, be brought to a due Accompt. And whereas al≈øo the Receipt of the Publique Exchequer at We≈øtmin≈øter is judged mo≈øt fit, and convenient for that purpo≈øe,

Be it Ordained by his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, by and with the Advice and Con≈øent of His Council, That from and after the four and twentyeth day of June, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred fifty and four, The ≈øaid Receipt ≈øhall be, and ≈øhall be called, The Receipt of the Exchequer of his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, and ≈øhall be kept and executed in the u≈øual and accu≈øtomed Places, Method, Manner, and Way of Receipt of Exchequer, as formerly. And that all and every Summ and Summs of Money, and other Payments, which upon and after the ≈øaid four and twentyeth day of June, One thou≈øand ≈øix hundred fifty and four, ≈øhall be received, or taken, or ≈øhall become due or payable to, or for the u≈øe of his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, and the Common-wealth, by any Commi≈ø≈øioner, Trea≈øurer, Receiver, Collector, Sheriff, Bayliff, Steward, E≈øcheator, or other Officer, Mini≈øter, or Per≈øon, Bodies Politique, or Corporate what≈øoever, for any Fee-farm Rents, Quit-rents, Dry-rents, Out-rents, Annual Tenths, either
of the Layty or Clergy, or for fir≈øt Fruits of the Clergy, or for or out of the Rents, I≈ø≈øues or Profits of any the Honours, Mannours, Lands, Tenements, Hereditaments, Royalties, Franchi≈øes, or other Revenues, Certain or Ca≈øual, Tithes Appropriate, Impropriations, or Rectories Impropriate, with their appurtenances, late of or belonging to the late King, Queen, and Prince, Arch-Bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Deans, Deans and Chapters, Arch-Deacons and Deacons, in right of their Offices, as al≈øo of Delinquents and Recu≈øants, or any of them, or for or in re≈øpect of any Debts due to the late King, Queen or Prince, Or to the late Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parlament, or forfeited by any the ≈øaid Delinquents or Recu≈øants to the Common-wealth, or for or in re≈øpect of any Compo≈øition, Contract, or Sale, of or for any the premi≈ø≈øes, or any part or parcel of them, or for or in re≈øpect of Cu≈øtoms and Sub≈øidies upon Merchandizes, New Impo≈øt and Exci≈øe, Sale, or other Di≈øpo≈øition of Prize Goods, or for or in re≈øpect of any Confi≈øcation, Seizure, Forfeiture, Fine, or other Penalty or Contempt, or upon, or by any Iudgement, Decree, Order or Award of any Court, Commi≈ø≈øioners or Committee thereunto Authorized; And all and every Summ and Summs of Money, and other Payments what≈øoever, which upon the ≈øaid four and twentyeth day of June ≈øhall be due, or from thenceforth ≈øhall ari≈øe, accrue, or grow due or payable to his Highne≈øs and the Common-wealth, by, or from any Per≈øon or Per≈øons what≈øoever, Bodies Politique, or Corporate, by all or any the Ways or Means
afore≈øaid, or by any other Waies or Means than are before ≈øpecified, ≈øhall be paid into the ≈øaid Receipt of the Exchequer, by all and every the Per≈øon and Per≈øons, Bodies Politique and Corporate, who ≈øhall receive, or be liable to pay the ≈øame, any Law, Statute, Ordinance or Order of Parlament, or any other Matter or Thing what≈øoever to the Contrary hereof, in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding. For the payment of which Moneys, and every of them, Tallies levyed and allowed according to the u≈øual and accu≈øtomed Cour≈øe of the Exchequer, with the Alteration of the words upon the Tally from Latine to Engli≈øh, ≈øhall be to every Per≈øon and Per≈øons, Bodies Politique and Corporate, ≈øo paying, and their Succe≈ø≈øors, Heirs, Execucutors, Admini≈øtrators, and A≈ø≈øigns, re≈øpectively, ≈øufficient Acquittance and Di≈øcharge.

And be it further Ordained and Declared by the Authority afore≈øaid, That from and after the ≈øaid four & twentyeth day of June, the ≈øaid Receipt of the Exchequer of His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, ≈øhall be governed and ordered; And the Moneys therein from time to time being and remaining, and to be there paid as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall be received and kept, and charged and accompted for, and al≈øo i≈ø≈øued and paid out (by Warrant, as is herein, and hereby declared) according to the ancient method, u≈øage and practice of the Receipt of the Exchequer, by ≈øuch Per≈øon and Per≈øons, Officer and Officers onely, and no other, than ≈øuch as His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector ≈øhall from time to time, by Letters Patents under the Great Seal, con≈øtitute and appoint. And that every Per≈øon and Per≈øons, Officer
and Officers to be hereafter in that behalf ≈øo con≈øtituted and appointed, as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall and may from time to time have, u≈øe, exerci≈øe, and enjoy, all and every the like lawfull Powers, Privileges, Preheminences and Authorities, in relation to his and their ≈øeveral Offices and Places, and the execution thereof, as any other Per≈øon or Per≈øons, Officer or Officers of the Receipt of the Exchequer at We≈øtmin≈øter, in the admini≈øtration or execution of their or any of their Offices or Places at any time heretofore lawfully have, or of right might have, had, u≈øed, or enjoyed. And ≈øhall have and receive for and in re≈øpect of his and their execution of, and attendance in and upon his and their ≈øaid Offices and Places re≈øpectively, ≈øuch moderate Fees, Wages, Rewards and Allowances onely, as His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, with the advice and con≈øent of His Council, by the ≈øaid Letters Patents, ≈øhall think fit to limit and appoint.

And be it further Ordained by the Authority afore≈øaid, That if any Per≈øon or Per≈øons, Officer or Officers ≈øo authorized as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall at any time directly or indirectly, upon any pretence what≈øoever, by colour of ≈øuch his or their Office or Imployment, take or receive any other or greater fee or fees, ≈øum or ≈øums of Money, or other Gift, Reward, or Gratuity what≈øoever, That then all and every ≈øuch Per≈øon and Per≈øons, Officer and Officers ≈øhall, upon proof or confe≈ø≈øion thereof before His Highne≈øs Council forfeit and lo≈øe his and their Place and Places, Office and Offices; and the Letters Patents in that behalf ≈øhall from thenceforth become void. And all and
every Per≈øon and Per≈øons, Officer and Officers ≈øo offending, ≈øhall al≈øo forfeit and pay treble the value of ≈øuch Fee or Fees, Sum or Sums of Money, Gift, Reward, or Gratuity, unto ≈øuch Per≈øon and Per≈øons, as ≈øhall ≈øue for the ≈øame, by Bill, Plaint, or Information in any Court of Record.

And be it further Ordained, That all and every the Sum and Sums of Money, which from and after the ≈øaid four and twentyeth day of June ≈øhall be brought and paid into the ≈øaid Receipt, ≈øhall be from time to time thence i≈ø≈øued and paid by Warrant and Authority under the Great Seal, or under the Privy Seal, and not otherwi≈øe.

But as to the i≈ø≈øuing of the Money mentioned in the nine and twentieth Article of the Government of the Common-wealth of England, Scotland and Ireland, and the Dominions thereto belonging, The ≈øame ≈øhall not be granted but by Con≈øent of Parlament, or of the Lord Protector and major part of the Council, in the Intervals of Parlaments.

Provided, That this Ordinance, or any thing therein conteined, ≈øhall not extend to any the Revenues of Ireland, or monies rai≈øed there for the publique u≈øe, until His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, or His Council, ≈øhall give Order therein.

Provided al≈øo, That this Ordinance, or any thing therein conteined, ≈øhall not extend to any the Lands, Tenements, Hereditaments, Revenues or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of, or belonging to His Highne≈øs the Lord Protector, or His Succe≈ø≈øors Lords Protectors, in any other Capacity than as Lord Protector onely.

div.head: Wedne≈øday June 21. 1654.
div.p: ORdered by his Highne≈øs the Lord Protector and His Council, That this Ordinance be forthwith Printed and Publi≈øhed,

closer.signed: Henry Scobell, Clerk of the Council.
